dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRAIG GILNER (16, handsome, but awkward) glides on his bi toward the Brooklyn Bridge. He is the only one on the streets. A rhythmic beating heart is the only sound we he

dialogues.speaker: BADOOM BADOOM BADOOM
dialogues.text: The heartbeat increases in pace as Craig nears the bridge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float behind Craig as he approaches the bridge’s first tower. Craig is still the only person there.

dialogues.speaker: BADOOM BADOOM BADOOM
dialogues.text: He arrives at the tower, steps off his bike, and looks ou over the East River.

dialogues.speaker: BADOOM BADOOM BADOOM
dialogues.text: He climbs up onto a steel girder. Walks to the edge, over the speeding traffic below, then out over the water.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Craig!? Craig looks behind him to find his mother (LYNN, early 40 father (GEORGE, mid 40s), and little sister (ALYSSA, 8) a standing by his bike.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: What were you planning to do with your bike, honey?!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t care about my bike! I’m killing myself!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But we spent a lot of money on that bike, Sport! We only ask that you take care of it!

dialogues.speaker: ALYSSA
dialogues.text: Think of me, Craig! I might want that bike when I grow up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I just didn’t think--

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: That’s right, honey, you weren’t thinking of us when you decided to do this, were you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Pretty selfish, I'd say. Have you thought about how this might affect your sister?

dialogues.speaker: ALYSSA
dialogues.text: I'll be traumatized for life. Craig stares at his family for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I-- A CAR HORN BLARES and Craig flinches, blinded by the onco headlights. He loses his footing on the thin metal plank. He SLIPS AND FALLS as his family watches in horror. CRAIG'S POV: hurling down toward the water below. At the moment before impact, the frame FREEZES a few feet above water--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the moment where I usually wake up in a sweaty panic. ANGLE ON CRAIG’S anguished face frozen in time.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But for some reason... this time was different-- The POV frame resumes action and Craig plunges into the water. TITLE: “IT’S KIND OF A FUNNY STORY”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig locks his bike to a rack in front of an illuminated emergency room sign. He turns towards the hospital. Overhead the sky is illuminated by a pre-dawn glow. SUPER: “SUNDAY: DAY 1”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig wanders into the bright, fluorescent-lit room, approaches the NURSE at the registration desk.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hi... I want to kill myself. Unphased, the nurse hands him a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Fill this out, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig waits near an ear-infected KID, when his attention shifts to the sliding doors. A man, dressed in blue docto scrubs, saunters in with a cup of coffee, takes a seat (unusually close) next to Craig. He is BOBBY (late 30s, s balding). Craig does his best to ignore him, until...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey. Craig turns to him. Upon closer inspection, he appears a too disheveled to be a doctor or nurse. He looks at Craig with an unhinged intensity.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You gotta cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Uh... no. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I just don’t smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No, I mean why are you in the E.R. at five o’clock on a Sunday morning?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Well, um, there’s been a lot going on in my head lately.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, um... I don’t really know how to describe it. Like there’s a girl...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: And, you know, this summer school application I’ve been nervous about.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Summer school.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s like this super prestigious--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: --Why would you want to spend your summer in school? Craig stares at Bobby for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You should be at Coney Island bird dogging chicks on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Are you a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You don’t really seem like a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Ever heard of Doogie Howser? Craig stares at Bobby, trying to make sense of the questi

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (standing up) I hope they fix whatever’s wrong with you.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks. Bobby stalks off, disappears around a corner.  INT. E.R. DOCTOR’S OFFICE - LATER DR. ISAIAH MAHMOUD, an E.R. resident (Indian, early 30s) takes Craig’s blood pressure.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: How long have you been feeling suicidal?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I’ve been depressed for about a year now. Thought about it a few times, but never like this. Never so... real.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Did anything specific happen today that might have triggered these feelings? Slight PUSH IN on Craig...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I had an easy answer for why I’m depressed. My father beat me. Or I was sexually abused. But none of that stuff has ever happened to me... It was just a normal Saturday. INT. AARON’S BEDROOM - EARLIER THAT DAY Craig and his friends lounge around the room, listening t Aaron's record collection. There is: AARON (not particula good-looking, but supremely self-confident), his girlfrie NIA (an ultra-hip, tightly-clad cutie), RONNY (a 1990s hi hop throwback), and SCUGGS (jew-fro). Ronny coughs, exhaling smoke, and passes a joint to Aaron who cuddles next to Nia on the bed. Everyone talks animatedly, except for Craig, who stares at Nia, longingl

dialogues.speaker: RONNY
dialogues.text: He practically had to strip search me to find it. It's like, dude, you're a security guard at a rock concert. Why are you taking your job so seriously?

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: He probably just wanted some free weed.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: How much did they get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eighth. But it was worth it. APW was the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: It was pretty jokes... But oh-eight was off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I need to go.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What-- you’re leaving? I didn’t even play Saucerful of Secrets yet.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just...

dialogues.speaker: SCUGGS
dialogues.text: Don’t bug Craig. He’s in the Craig zone.

dialogues.speaker: RONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s Craig-ing out! They all laugh. Craig forces a chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig rides his bike over the bridge, stops to answer his phone.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey... INT. AARON’S BEDROOM - DAY Nia playfully pushes Aaron off her.

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Hey Craig. I forgot to ask you to cover for me tonight, in case my parents call or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh... You're staying over Aaron's?

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: I told them there was some school sleep over. They’re a little suspicious, so they might call.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No problem.  Craig hangs up, looks out over the East River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig's family sits around the table for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey there, Craigers. How's the Franklin Gates application coming along? Craig stares at his dad for a beat, then VOMITS on the ta

dialogues.speaker: ALYSSA
dialogues.text: Gross. Craig's parents look to him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (to Lynn) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: (with Dr. Mahmoud’s voice) Craig? Anything you can think of that may have set you off? INT. ARGENON HOSPITAL - E.R. DOCTOR’S OFFICE - PRESENT Dr. Mahmoud waits for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um... no. Nothing unusual.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Are you taking any medication?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Zoloft. But I stopped.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Did your doctor take you off the medication?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No. I just stopped on my own.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Oh... you shouldn’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your parents know where you are? Craig shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Well, Craig, you don’t seem to be in immediate danger to yourself, so I think we should call your parents, tell them what happened, and refer you to one of our out-patient services.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: But I need help now. The hotline said you'd help me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: I understand you’re upset, but the people we admit to the hospital are very sick.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I am too. Can’t you, like, give me something...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAHMOUD
dialogues.text: Not without parental consent. Look, this is serious business, Craig. We very rarely take in patients your age. I think it would be best if we tried to handle this without--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe I'm not explaining right... how serious. See, my school is really-- and not just my school-- it's like I throw up sometimes because everything feels like it's building up. And everyone else seems like they're totally handling everything-- like my friends, right? Aaron and Nia-- They're both so... But not me. I like sweat all the time. I'm sweating now, aren't I? Craig wipes his forehead, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You know what I mean? Dr. Mahmoud doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m scared, okay? I can’t go back out there... I don’t know what... I might do something... I just need some help. Please. I need you to help me. Dr. Mahmoud stares at Craig, concerned. He thinks it over INSERT: Dr. Mahmoud signs the admittance form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow NURSE SMITTY, a thin, bearded hippy-looking dud blue jeans, as he leads Craig off the elevator. Craig notices a sign on the wall reading ADULT PSYCHIATRIC with arrow pointing to the right. Smitty leads Craig towards a set of heavy double doors labeled THREE NORTH. Smitty flashes his ID, and the Three North SECURITY GUARD buzzes them inside. After they pass through the threshold, the doors shut, an the lock echoes through the corridors. ON CRAIG, peering over his shoulder at the prison-like me doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cute, West-Indian Nurse, MONICA, sips coffee behind the desk. Nurse Smitty shuffles papers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Welcome to Three North, Craig. Let’s go over some rules. First rule of Three North: we do NOT talk about Three North. This grabs Craig’s attention. Smitty cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: That gets me every time. Craig forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What exactly is Three North?

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Our adult psychiatric floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I’m only sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Our teen floor is undergoing renovations, so all teens are here with the adults.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: And you'll be expected to act like one while you’re with us. Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: So, starting tomorrow, you'll be following the schedule and participating in the group activities. She hands Craig a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Our floor has a point system, whereby patients get privileges for participating in activities and meals, and lose privileges for non- participation and/or acting out. INSERT: A schedule outlining the hour-by-hour itinerary f the week. Includes things like: BREAKFAST, VITALS, THERAP (GP. #1), ARTS & CRAFTS, BINGO, LUNCH.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: In the meantime, we’ll contact your family, and they can bring over a change of clothes, toothbrush, that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um, well, I don’t think I’1l be here that long. I have school tomorrow, SO... Monica and Smitty exchange knowing glances.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: You’1l have to discuss that with Doctor Minerva. Now, very important... do you have any sharp objects on you? Pocket knife? Keys?  Craig hands her his keys.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Good. We’ll need your cell phone and belt, too. And your shoe laces.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Shoe laces?

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: We can’t take any chances. Craig hands over his phone and watches as Monica seals it inside a plastic bag with his keys and shoelaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smitty leads Craig (minus shoelaces) down the hall. They pass several other PATIENTS, including a TWEAKED-OUT MAN wearing an oversized Backstreet Boys t-shirt. He makes a ZAPPING noise in Craig’s direction. Smitty spots a woman in a professional skirt suit approaching. She is DR. EDEN MINERVA (late 40s), the staf psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dr. Minerva...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Hey Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: This is our newest patient, Craig Gilner.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Hi Craig. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um... just, like... you know...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: You just get settled in. We’1ll talk later, okay? Nice to meet you, Craig. Smitty and Craig continue down the hall, where a patient, JIMMY, smiles to Craig. He has one tooth.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, it’ll come to ya.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Jimmy.  Craig nervously steps past Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Jimmy’s schizophrenic.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Is there a place here for people more like me?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: We have all kinds of patients here. (calling 0.S.) Bobby, my man! Camera TRACKS IN on BOBBY-- the same guy who sat next to Craig in the E.R. As he glides down the hall in SLOW-MO Craig gets a better look at him. No longer wearing doctor scrubs, Bobby sports a well-worn grey wool sweater. set eyes and rough edges betray a hard-lived past.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout a tour for our new friend, Craig, here?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure thing, babe.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Bobby’11 show you around while we fix up your room. See you guys in a jiff. Smitty splits and Craig follows Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What’s a jiff?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: A jiff?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: This guy, Smitty, is always like, “Do this in a jiff, that in a jiff.”

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I think it just means, like, a short period of time. Bobby doesn’t seem to care about Craig’s answer.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So, is this like a mental ward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a ward, a hospital... They turn a corner out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby leads Craig into a large multi-purpose room, where or so PATIENTS are scattered about.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We spend a lot of time in here. Right there you got your dining room situation; rec room area is over there. They got a record player, but everything's scratched. Craig notices a ping-pong table by the windows.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Folks play table tennis sometimes. Did they tell you about the points?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: For ping-pong?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Some people call it ping-pong, but I think that trivializes the sport. Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But I’m talking about the other points. You need’m for privileges, like hanging in the rec room, trips to the gift shop, shit like that. Craig makes eye contact with a white-bearded guy, ROGER, appears to stare straight through Craig into another dimension.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, man, if you’re really interested, you can join them.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Join them? Uh, no, I’m cool, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Cool Craig. Copy that. Let’s move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby points out a sliding latch on the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, this is the shower. It doesn’t have a lock, see? So when you’re inside, you put this to occupied. Bobby slides the latch back and forth, alternately reveal VACANT and OCCUPIED.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I get it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure, babe, but nobody else does, so they’1l walk right in while you’re scrubbin’ your nuts. Craig cracks a smile, follows Bobby down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Craig emerge around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: There’s one in the other hall too, but I wouldn’t use it. It bothers Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Who’s Solomon? No answer. They approach a pay phone near a bench.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: This is where you call people-- if you got people. Or they can call you too. Bobby gestures to the TV room behind a glass window.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: TV room is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig notices a teenage girl (16), wearing an Iggy Pop t- shirt, seated at a table in the corner. She is NOELLE. Sh glances up from her notebook, revealing several scars fro cuts on her face. Craig stares at her for a beat too long

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Oh, my God! Are you okay? Craig quickly checks himself, but can’t find anything wr He looks back to Noelle, who shoots him a subtle grin and gets back to her notebook. Bobby cracks up, leads Craig away.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Noelle. One of the teens. Did they tell you about the renovations?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jesus, I thought you was older. You look too stressed for sixteen, man. You should try to relax, maybe get a girlfriend, or sump’m.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m working on it. Bobby shoots Craig a crooked smile.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So what do you do here, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Same thing you do.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You're a patient? What were you doing in the emergency room this morning?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The ER has the best coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: They just let you out? Bobby smiles, puts his finger to his lips, makes a shushi sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you in for? Bobby hesitates, and Craig senses the inappropriateness o the question.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Uh... Sorry. Bobby stares at Craig, sizes him up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bet your room’s ready. Let’s find smitty. INT. THREE NORTH PATIENT’S ROOM - DAY The light flicks on to reveal a man burrowed under bed co in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Muqtada, it’s almost lunch! Wake up, you have a new roommate. MUQTADA, a gray-bearded Egyptian man, doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey. No response.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Craig) Don’t take it personal. He doesn’t talk much and he’s never left the room... Okay, guys, lunch in five. Smitty exits, and Craig sits at the edge of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What do they have for lunch? Muqtada grumbles something incomprehensible.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry? Muqtada takes the blanket and puts it over his head. Crai surveys the room. This isn’t quite what he had in mind wh he asked for help. After an uncomfortable beat, he goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, turn out light. Craig obliges, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig accosts Dr. Minerva, who is now doing rounds with a staff of INTERNS.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Dr. Minerva. Look, I’m, uh... (faking casual) I’m feeling much better now. I was feeling bad this morning, but I think I’m okay now. So, um, you know, I’d like to go home. If that’s cool. Dr. Minerva leafs through papers on her clipboard, finds Craig's form.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: It says here you’re suicidal and asked to be admitted.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I thought you guys would be able to do something quick. Like give me some medication to make me feel better. I didn't think I’d be... committed. I really don’t think I belong here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: A lot of patients feel that way at first. Just give it a little time.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How little?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Five days.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Five days?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Definitely not more than thirty. We’l1l have an evaluation to see if you're ready to leave Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: But I can’t be here until Thursday! I’‘1ll miss school. My friends will find out where I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s nothing to be ashamed of, Craig. Depression is a medical illness. If you were diabetic would you be embarrassed by that?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, can I at least talk to my mom about this before--

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Of course, Craig. I just spoke with her myself, and she’s very anxious to see you. Dr. Minerva nods and smiles to someone behind Craig, then drifts away.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Craig! Craig turns to find his mom running at him followed by Ge and Alyssa. She nearly tackles him with a hug, and we FRE

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t blame my parents for how messed up I am. Okay, so my dad works too much... ANGLE ON George, frozen in time, messaging on his Blackbe

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And my mom’s a little out of touch. ANGLE ON Lynn, her face oddly contorted as she hugs Craig

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And my sister’s some kind of child genius. ANGLE ON Alyssa staring straight ahead without emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But it’s not like I was never hugged as a child or anything. In fact, they’ve been pretty supportive through all this. They’re always on the lookout for new ways to fix me. The following sequence presents the various ways they’ve tried to fix him in the past. Craig maintains the same deadpan expression throughout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHINESE ACUPUNCTURIST applies needles to Craig’s back, while his mom looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and his dad attempt to do sit-ups on some kind of enormous rubber work-out balls. Craig falls off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig practices bikram yoga with his mom in 105 degree he He’s drenched in sweat, but not quite feeling the vibe. INT. CRAIG’S BEDROOM - ANOTHER DAY On a ping-pong table that barely fits inside his small bedroom, Craig serves to his dad, who slams the ball back him. Craig doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THREE NORTH
dialogues.text: CRAIG AND HIS FAMILY IN PRESENT TIME. The still frame resumes action.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: We knew you were going through a hard time, but we had no idea you were... that it was... I’m so proud of you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: This is the bravest thing you’ve ever done. You made the right decision coming here.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Because I was kind of having second thoughts...

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: We talked to the doctor and they need to keep you here for a few days. For observation. I think it’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: But I don’t think you understand. Some of the people here are seriously messed up. Like I don’t think my roommate’s left the room in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you expect? It is a mental ward.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s not a ward. It’s a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: It’s just five days, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: They told me AT LEAST five.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Well, we thought it was best to leave it up to the doctor’s discretion. I mean, we've tried, but... These people are professionals. They know how to help you in ways, well, that maybe we can’t. Craig watches Lynn as she takes a deep breath, trying har hold herself together.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: It seems like a nice place. Right, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, when can I join?

dialogues.speaker: ALYSSA
dialogues.text: Me too. Can I stay too?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: We can visit, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: They took my cell phone, so some people might try to call the house. Please don’t tell them where I am. Lynn nods, hands Craig a small duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Here are some clothes and toiletries. Let us know if you need anything else.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And I brought this... in case you have some free time in here. George hands Craig a stack of academic-looking forms. Cr tentatively takes them. Lynn shoots George a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: But don’t worry about that application stuff right now. Just get some rest. Try to eat something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A serving of curry chicken is placed on Craig's tray. Cra winces.

dialogues.speaker: SERVER
dialogues.text: Want broccoli?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I have trouble eating.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Craig, George, Lynn, and Alyssa eat dinner at a corner bo

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The first time I experienced stress vomiting was at Slooters downtown.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, Craig, how’s your Intro to Wall Street class? Craig vomits on the table. His family stares in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I think I’m depressed.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ever since, my eating has kinda become a litmus test for how well I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO CRAIG IN THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Tray in hand, Craig surveys the room, finds an empty sect between a group of teenage girls and a table of grown men (Bobby among them). Craig sits in the neutral territory, at the far end of th girls’ table. There are three: JENNIFER has black hair wi a blue streak in it; she’s a pretty hot teen transvestite BECCA is a big girl. Noelle is the third.  Craig stares at his food for a beat. He can’t help but overhear the girls playing some kind of game, listing off names.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Hunter Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Virginia Woolf.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Ian Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Dude from Joy Division. Hung himself.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Kurt Cobain.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Freud.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Cobain to Freud?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Drug addicts.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Nice. Okay, um... Ernest Hemmingway-- (off their blank looks) Old man beards. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Salvador Allende.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Jesus, girl, can you pick somebody we've heard of for once?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Chilean president. Shot himself rather than surrender to a fascist military coup.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it counts.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: If he was going to die anyway, it doesn’t count.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: (to Craig) Hey, new guy.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: No, the other new guy. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ah, Craig.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Well, Ah Craig, what do you think? Does Salvador Allende count as a celebrity suicide? Craig stares at her in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um, I don’t...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, kid... Don’t get caught up in the girls’ morbid mind games. Come eat with the men. Craig looks back and forth between the two intimidating groups.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Craig. Who knows? Maybe one day you’ll make the list. Craig stares at the giggling girls, then slides a few fee closer to Bobby’s table. Bobby introduces Craig to the others.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Craig, meet my old pal Johnny.  Craig nods to JOHNNY (mid 30s with a 1950s rock-a-billy hairdo).

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And this clown is Humble. HUMBLE, a pudgy former Kojak stand-in, nods hello. He spe with a mouth full of food.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: You gotta girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He’s workin’ on it.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: They got some cute ones your age.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I had a lotta women in my day, kid.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to act so surprised, but yes, yes I had a lotta women. And, no, I’m not the best looking cat on the street. But you wanta know the secret to keeping any woman under your spell? Craig eagerly awaits the answer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: That’s it. But it don’t hurt if you can play guitar.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don’t mess with the kid’s head; he’s already screwed up enough.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: Why you so screwed up, kid?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind your business, Humble.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: That’s cool. But you should know, Craig, if you don’t open up, you’re not going to heal. Humble slides away. The others continue eating, but Craig hasn’t touched his plate.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What’s the pot up to?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Eleven? Yesterday we had twelve.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Humble ate a buck.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Humble ate a buck?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: The professor bet him a dollar he wouldn’t eat it... He won.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What is the world coming to? Bunch of freaks.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What’s the money for?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Pizza party. We’re sick of eating this crap. They say we can have one, but we gotta pay for it ourselves...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I have eight dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well don’t go bragging about it, Craig. People in here don’t have anything. Learn to show some humility.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn’t mean--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Don’t worry about it. You’re young still. Smitty strolls behind Craig, notices his uneaten food.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: You get two points for eating, Craig. Craig stares at his plate. Tries a bite. Throws up. Everyone stares at Craig in shock. Noelle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sorry. INT. DR. MINERVA’S OFFICE - DAY CLOSE ON Dr. Minerva’s breasts behind a rust red sweater. She's looking at Craig's file, off-screen. Craig glances up from her breasts, noting how the shade o her lipstick matches her sweater to perfection.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: So Craig, how are you adjusting to Three North?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Uh... Okay, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Dr. Mahmoud wrote that you were taking Zoloft, but went off it three weeks ago. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Do you see a therapist?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Dr. Yanof prescribed me the Zoloft. I see her every, you know... month or so.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Why did you stop taking it?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I guess I felt better. Like I didn’t need it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s because it was working.  Craig shrugs, smiles awkwardly, as Dr. Minerva scribbles something in the file.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Can you describe for me how you were feeling right before coming here this morning? Craig shifts uncomfortably in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I dunno. Depressed... anxious... stressed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Have you been experiencing more stress than usual lately? Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Any reason in particular?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, there’s this Franklin Gates Summer Semester thing that my Dad-- Well, that I really want to get into. The application’s due in a week and I haven’t even looked at it yet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s like, every time I think about it, my mind starts this cycling thing about not getting in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: What would happen if you didn’t get in? CAMERA PUSHES IN on Craig, who shoots us a subtle glance.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What would happen if I didn’t get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON blank extracurricular section of application.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then I wouldn’t be able to put it on my college applications. Which means...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK past rows of college-age STUDENTS to 16 year-old Cr eagerly raising his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Gilner.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .--I wouldn’t get into a good college.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE CRAIG
dialogues.text: (answering his professor) But not even Adam Smith could have foreseen the inequities of modern capitalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN on Craig (still sixteen) behind the Presidential podium.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If I didn’t get into a good college, I wouldn't have a good job.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad you asked that, Helen. Diffusing the situation in Iran through unilateral diplomacy is my top priority as Commander in Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An MTV CRIBS episode exploring Craig’s presidential home. Craig, wearing a silk and fox fur bathrobe invites the vi crew through his front door.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Which means I wouldn’t be able to afford a good lifestyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dapper Craig, sporting an Armani suit and sunglasses, toasts martini glasses with his glamorous girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So I wouldn’t be able to find a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours down, as a sad Craig stares at the clouds thro the window.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Which means I'd probably get depressed. INT. CRAIG’S THREE NORTH BEDROOM- DAY CLOSE ON Craig in bed, staring off.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So I wouldn’t be able to get out of bed. We ZOOM OUT to reveal Craig curled in fetal position on Mugqtada’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I’d end up like Muqtada in a place like this for the rest of my life. Craig turns to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So-- what would happen if I didn't get in...?! INT. DR. MINERVA’S OFFICE - DAY Craig stares at Dr. Minerva. A bead of sweat drips down h forehead. He gives a shrug and awkward smile.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I dunno. It’s hard to explain. She hands him a tissue to wipe his sweat. He does.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Well, do you have anyone you can explain it to? Friends? Family?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um... I have friends... and family. But it’s not always easy...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: It's important to have a support system. People you can really talk to. Craig nods, wipes his forehead again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been experiencing any symptoms... other than sweating?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Eating. I have problems eating. I can’t, you know, keep it down. Dr. Minerva takes more notes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: So we'll get you back on the Zoloft, and you'll start group activities tomorrow. We’1ll check in again on Tuesday. Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: If I’m, you know... feeling better, you think I can get out of here, like, tomorrow? I have school and this application, and--

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Five days, Craig. Minimum. This might feel like a strange place at first, but try to make the most of it. We’1l hold your evaluation on Thursday. Craig nods, looks out the office window to the bustling Brooklyn street-life below. TITLE OVER BLACK: “MONDAY: DAY TWO”

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It’s Monday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig's eyes pop open in bed. He looks over to Muqtada, SNORING LOUDLY in the bed next to him.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be waking up next to some depressive middle-aged Egyptian dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig awkwardly extends one arm, keeping the door shut, w the other lathers up his body.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be showering on a co-ed floor in a stall without a lock. Jennifer attempts to enter the room, wearing a shower ca but Craig’s security arm forces the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TRACK along a line of adult patients, downing their me in dixie cups. We STOP on little Craig at the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be lining up for meds behind schizophrenics and sociopaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stares at his breakfast burrito.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It’s Monday; I should be in school... But I guess that’s what got me here in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring white-bread High-Schoolers going to class.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When my parents went to school, they just went to the one closest to their house. Makes sense, right? A lot of places are still like this: Cleveland, probably Denver. But not New York.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You've got schools for science geeks like-- We TRACK along a complicated physics equation on the dry erase board, stopping on a SCIENCE GEEK who turns to came

dialogues.speaker: SCIENCE GEEK
dialogues.text: Bronx High School of Science.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Schools for thespians... Two TEEN ACTORS rehearse on stage, while a young DIRECTOR addresses us from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Guardia High School for the Performing Arts.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Do-gooders. Young activists walk the picket line holding signs, while their teen leader addresses us.

dialogues.speaker: DO-GOODER
dialogues.text: El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But the most competitive of all New York City Public Schools is this one. Executive Pre-Professional. My school.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This billionaire philanthropist named Gerard Lutz set it up in conjunction with the public school system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FLOATS down the hall with KIDS passing in and out frame on the way to class.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So it’s not some private school for elite upper-east-siders. You can be on welfare and food stamps or your parents can own an island in the South Pacific. It doesn’t matter. Craig emerges from the group, staring into camera.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You’1ll be accepted as long as you’re one of the 800 smartest, most accomplished students in the five boroughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH ON a YOUNG INDIAN GIRL seated at her desk. She glan up from her book, Noam Chomsky’s “Hegemony or Survival.”  SUPER: SAHARA PATEL - SAT: 2380 GRE: 1530 (5.5 Writing) LSAT: 174 MCAT: 42 (S Writing) FLASH ON a YOUNG AFRICAN-AMERICAN KID. He glances up from his book, Darwin's “Origin of Species.” SUPER: JAMES HOWARD - 3 time winner of the F. Gates Young Genius Trophy (2003, 2005, 2006) FLASH ON a WHITE HIPSTER KID - Craig’s friend, Aaron, rea from Joe Sacco’s graphic novel, “Palestine.” SUPER: AARON FITZCARRALDO - Winner of the inaugural Ediso Young Inventors Cup (2006); 2 time winner of the F. Gates Young Genius Trophy (2002, 2004); Doubles badminton Olymp gold medalist (2008) FLASH ON 14-year-old Craig. He reads from the book “Be Mo Chill.”

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: We hold for a beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There must have been a serious clerical error, because somehow... I got in. INT. AARON’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - FLASHBACK Seated on the floor around an enormous scattered record collection, Aaron and Nia look off-screen at Craig.

dialogues.speaker: AARON/NIA
dialogues.text: (in unison) Me too. Aaron and Nia exchange surprised looks.

dialogues.speaker: AARON/NIA
dialogues.text: (again in unison) You too? They crack up laughing. Nia playfully punches Aaron’s arm and we FREEZE--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That’s my best friend, Aaron, getting flirt-punched by Nia for the first time. There were many more of those. Followed by hand-holding...

dialogues.speaker: B51
dialogues.text: csl 51 FLASH ON a still frame of Aaron and Nia strolling A51 through the hall, smiling and holding hands as if ina Mentos commercial.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Kissing... FLASH ON a still frame of Aaron and Nia smooching in the school stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...and eventually... sex. FLASH ON a blank white screen. C51

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don’t like to picture that one.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What I would give to be flirt-punched by Nia just once. The frame resumes action. Aaron and Nia stare at each oth for an extended moment before Aaron goes in for the full flirt-tackle.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And so it began... CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stares at his food, unsure. Next to him, Humble and Johnny eat as they flip through a motorcycle magazine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Look at those flames! I always wanted a Harley with big red flames. Humble points out the girl on the bike.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: You can have the bike. I just want the beavers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hey, Bobby, check out this bike.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don’t get caught up on a bunch of stuff I can’t have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, it’s just for fun, bro.

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, what’s your prob, Bob? We PAN over to Craig's friend, Aaron, seated next to Bobb Of course, he is only there in Craig’s imagination.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: It’s just for fun. Life is fun. And easy. And you CAN have those things. Women, Harleys, perfect test scores. You just need the brains and the balls to go get’m. (taking a bite of breakfast burrito) Mmm, this is good. We PAN back to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It’s not fun; it’s propaganda. Telling me I need all that - nice clothes, cars, hot chicks...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .--iphones, Jordans, skinny jeans, zit cream, self esteem, abs of steel, chicken soup for the soul...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But I could give a shit about all that. Humble notices Craig’s untouched tray.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: You gonna eat your burrito, Craig?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Naw. I’m not hungry. You can have it. Humble reaches over, grabs the burrito.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Put it back, Humble.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: He said I could have it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Craig's gotta eat too. Put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a hike, Bob, he’s not hungry. Bobby charges across the table, grabs the burrito, and pu it back on Craig’s tray. Craig stares at the torn and knuckled burrito.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um, thanks, Bobby, but I’m really not--

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I’ll eat it! Waddling in from a nearby table, the Professor quickly gr the burrito, puts it on her own tray.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: Hey, I called it first. Humble lunges for the burrito, but the Professor tries to shield it with her body.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Nice burrito block!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It don’t belong to either of you!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Really, guys, I don’t think... Bobby intervenes, snatches the burrito, but not before th Professor sneaks a quick bite. Smitty approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: People calm down. Everyone quickly settles in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (with mouthful of burrito) I didn’t do nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: It was my burrito. Bobby hands what’s left of the mashed burrito to Craig.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s really okay. I don’t need it.  Bobby stares at Craig for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fine... Bobby drops the remains of the burrito on Humble’s tray.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ..-what do I care? Don’t eat. Bobby takes his own tray, walks off. Craig exchanges awkw looks with the others.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: You guys know we have like fifty burritos in the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients sit in a loose circle around Dr. Minerva. Cr observes silently, sneaking occasional glances at Noelle, seated on the opposite side of the circle.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: I understand there was an incident this morning. Would anyone care to talk about it? Something involving a breakfast burrito. Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It was between Bobby and Humble. Ask them.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: I was just interested in hearing it from an impartial observer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, if you want my opinion, I think Bobby’s been on edge because of his interview and he’s lashing out because he’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Interesting observation, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Johnny, you know my hemorrhoids are flarin’ up again. Make sure everyone knows about that, too.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hemorrhoids! It’ll come to ya! Some laughter from the patients. Craig smiles, sneaks a at Noelle across the room. She’s not paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Bobby, it’s okay if you want to keep your feelings private, but you should know it’s perfectly normal to be nervous about your interview tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m not nervous about the interview.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: Then what is it, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR

dialogues.text: Yeah, I want the shirt.

dialogues.text: Craig?

dialogues.text: Do you mind if it has yellow armpit stains? Bobby stares at Craig.

dialogues.text: Sorry, dumb joke. Noelle SNORTS out a laugh.

dialogues.text: Hey, Craig, it’s me, um... The image FREEZES--

dialogues.text: Yo Craig, I'm staying at Nia’s tonight. I need you to cover for me if my dad calls. Holla back, son! Craig hangs up, notices an old, academic-type lady waitin for the phone nearby. She is “THE PROFESSOR.” He quickly dials...

dialogues.text: Hey, Nia. What's up? We INTERCUT between Craig and Nia in her bedroom. D54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just finishing my Gates Summer app. I'll freak if I don't get in.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.text: What's up with you?

dialogues.text: Uh, I’ve just been feeling kinda, you know...

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve noticed... Is that why you weren’t in school today?

dialogues.text: Yeah... Like I’ve been feeling pretty shitty, so... I stayed home.

dialogues.text: You know...

dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.text: Look, I’ve never told anybody this. Not even Aaron. So you have to promise not to tell him. But if it makes you feel any better... I’m on Prozac.

dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, for like over a year now.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: I know. It’s a little embarrassing.

dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.text: We are so screwed up!

dialogues.text: (whispering) One second, please.

dialogues.text: Um, yeah, I guess.

dialogues.text: Good. The last thing I need is for people to find out I’ve been institutionalized. I’m talking cataclysmic disaster the proportions of which have no limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. I was just bringing you the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (re: the photo) She’s cute, right?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is she yours?

dialogues.text: (nods ) Veronica. Like the Elvis Costello song. Craig stares at Bobby, clearly not aware of the song.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Eight and three-quarters. That’s what she says. Craig smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, good luck on your interview. What’s it for, if you don’t mind me asking?

dialogues.text: It’s for a group home. I basically need a place to live when they kick me outta here on Thursday.

dialogues.text: Kick you out?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Insurance only covers a certain number of days here, so come Thursday, I’m gone. Whether I got a place to sleep or not.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Wow. I guess you’re under a lot of pressure, then.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s not like a summer school application, but yeah, I guess...  Craig smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Let me know if you need somebody to practice with, or something.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Like a practice interview. So you’re better prepared.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wanta try?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Now?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. (as interviewer) Okay, um, have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Wait, hold on. Bobby grabs the new shirt, turns his back to Craig, and buttons it up. He spins around, ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s do it. They sit on opposite beds, facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s see... Why do you think you're qualified to live in this group home?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well... I guess because I’1l be homeless if you don’t accept me. Craig stares at Bobby, not sure where to go from here.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Okay, good. I think you’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Really? I didn’t sound too desperate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was very sincere... But maybe you could try to focus on the positive things you would get from the experience rather than, you know...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The negative.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Exactly. Like what do you think you can bring to the home? Something special only you can offer. Bobby thinks hard.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It can be anything. Maybe you have a great attitude?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You always clean up after yourself?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You know what? I think maybe sometimes in these situations it’s okay to bend the truth a little.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to raise anyone's expectations and then disappoint them.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That’s it! You’re pragmatic! Right there. That’s what you tell them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think you’1l do great.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks, babe. You up for a match of table tennis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I’m actually pretty terrible at it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Relax babe. It’s just for fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby holds the ball, addressing Craig on the opposite si

dialogues.text: We play a lot around here, but the problem is most people are too zonked out on their meds to compete. Bobby serves to Craig’s partner, Roger, but the ball just bounces past him. After a beat, Roger swings for it. Crai can’t help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No, but-- I never said those things. She’s a liar... Please, baby. Baby, baby, please, listen, listen.... Johnny notices Craig nearby, pauses for dramatic effect.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: ...I love you. You know, I love you... That’s right. Sure. Don’t worry about it. Of course, I forgive you, baby. Johnny gives Craig a thumbs up and a smile. Craig looks o awed by his mastery of women, when... .--Noelle approaches. Craig plays it cool, as she takes a seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You came.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, like, I had other plans, but I cancelled them.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Good. I thought I mighta scared you off yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, celebrity suicide. Kinda weird. Craig notices several old scars on Noelle’s forearm, peak out of her bunched up sleeve. Seeing this, Noelle subtly pulls her sleeves over her palms. Beat.

dialogues.text: Okay, check it out... We’re gonna play a different game now.

dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I ask you a question and you ask me a question.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Do we answer them?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It’s up to you, but no matter what, you have to finish with a question. Here we go... You ready?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I said finish with a question. Are you stupid?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Uh, no... Are you?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: There you go. Do you think I’m gross looking?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No, you look awesome.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What’s your question?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Why'd you invite me here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was nice that you loaned Bobby your shirt. Don’t you think this is a good way to get to know someone?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sure. Have you played this before?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Not in here. Are you a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So... How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Oooh, nice transition, Craig. Twenty- one days. Who brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I checked myself in, I guess. Kinda by accident. The suicide hotline said to come. Why are you here so long?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: They think I might cut myself again. Why'd you call the suicide hotline?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I guess because I didn’t actually want to kill myself... even though I kind of did. Does that make sense? Noelle nods.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: So, why did you kind of want to kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Depression... stress. Have you ever heard of the Franklin Gates University--

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: --Scholastic Summer Semester? Yes. So you messed up the application or something?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No, I mean, I haven’t even started yet.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Finish with a question. Isn’t it due on Friday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez. Do you have to remind me?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Sorry. So are you some kind of brain or something?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I work hard, but I’m not that smart. I get Bs. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t care too much about school. The teachers think I have a problem with authority. Where do you go?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Executive Pre-Professional. You?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Delfin. You’re not some kind of school uniform perv, are you?

dialogues.text: You guys wear uniforms?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: See, I knew it! (flinching) Is there a bug on my face? Craig examines her face, finds a loose eyelash near her e He holds it up for her to see.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Make a wish. Noelle thinks for a beat, blows it away.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Is the game over yet?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Sure. Craig leans back, takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Are you still playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... are you? They both laugh. Noelle jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I‘1l race you to arts and crafts. Noelle takes off down the hall at full speed. Craig watch her for a second, then gives chase. As they pass Smitty..

dialogues.text: Hey, no running, please!

dialogues.text: This is free period arts recreational therapy for you latecomers. The room full of PATIENTS turn their heads toward Craig a Noelle, just now taking their seats in the back. Bobby cranes his neck, whispers over his shoulder to Crai

dialogues.text: Cool Craig. Still workin’ on it?

dialogues.text: It’s not what you think.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Call me crazy, but I think you guys were probably out there playing the question game.

dialogues.text: Oh, then I guess it is what you think.

dialogues.text: Thought so. Joanie strolls up to Craig, introduces herself.

dialogues.text: I’m Joanie, the recreation director.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Craig.

dialogues.text: Materials are on the table, Craig.

dialogues.text: Oh, that’s okay. I don’t really draw.

dialogues.text: Sure you do. It doesn’t have to be representative. It can be abstract.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That’s okay, I’1l just-- Joanie turns to the class.

dialogues.text: How about beavers?

dialogues.text: Humble, we do not draw the sort of beavers you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: That’s a very nice drawing, Humble. Roger, from Saturday’s ping-pong match, calls out in gene

dialogues.text: Rolling pin!

dialogues.speaker: JOANIE
dialogues.text: What was that, Roger? That’s very good. What did you say? But Roger clams up, won’t repeat it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (to Noelle) This is weird.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: She won’t get off your back until you draw something. Anything. I bet you have some crazy stuff in that messed up little mind of yours. dialogues.text: Craig, honey, what's the matter?

dialogues.text: I can't do it. Five years old and I’m already a failure.

dialogues.text: Craig, you can’t just trace freehand and expect it to be perfect.

dialogues.text: Is this the loony bin!? Aaron cracks up, and we FREEZE on his mangled expression.
