dialogues.text: Okay, I’ve been putting this off, but I guess you should know more about my best friend, Aaron. He’s the kind of guy that life just comes easy to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK down a row of students receiving their graded tests 94, 97, 96, 98... Craig gets an 82%, and Aaron scores a 1

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He’s got a 4.6 GPA! I don’t even see how that’s possible. And he’11l probably get into the Gates Summer Program, and claim something like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is juggling apples in front of his many friends, bu turns to address the camera while keeping the apples revolving in only his left hand:

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: I didn’t even apply to that thing. They totally recruited me. Whatever, it’ll look good on my college apps. He gets back to juggling two-handed for his friends.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not that he’d need it... His extracurriculars are out of control. I mean Aaron does everything. FLASH ON AARON sliding into home during a baseball A64 game. Craig is among the fans in the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He plays sports. FLASH ON a dark screening room, where Aaron is B64 watching an old film noir from the 1930s, however... ...ON THE SCREEN, in classic trenchcoat-noir regalia, Cra emerges from a dark shadow, turns to us in the audience..

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: He started a film society. FLASH ON Aaron connecting a shiny, futuristic cable C64 from his record player to a laptop computer. Craig appear in a Quicktime window in the corner of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (addressing us from the computer ) He invented that adapter thing that converts vinyl albums to mp3s. Nia enters the room, starts making out with Aaron. Mid- smooch, Aaron reaches for his computer mouse, closes the Quicktime window with a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I just couldn’t compete...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig speaks into the phone. We INTERCUT between A658 the hospital and Aaron's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How’d you get this number?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: My girl gave it to me. What’s it like in there, dude?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How do you know where I am?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: C’mon Craig, we go to the same school. I did a reverse number search.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Is there a class for that?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Seriously, how’d you end up in Adult Psych? Do they serve beer in there?  Craig hears laughter, and then Ronny, jumps on the line.

dialogues.speaker: RONNY
dialogues.text: Dude, can you get me any Vicodin? More laughter, but Nia protests.

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Guys, leave him alone! Aaron muscles the phone away from Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Seriously, Craig, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I had a bad night.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What do you mean, a bad night?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m just, you know, feeling...

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Dude, you just need to chill more. Your problem is you never chill. I’m gonna be chilling tonight; where you gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Here. I’m gonna be here.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Don’t be a girl. You know if I was in a mental ward, you’d call me up and give me shit.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s not a ward; it’s a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You seriously don’t know? They’re, like, two completely different--

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: --Ohmigod, Craig, there is so nothing wrong with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there is. I’m depressed. I take pills for it... ask Nia.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Ask Nia what?

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Craig!

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Forget it. Maybe if you weren’t such a dick, people would talk to you more and you'd know this kind of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Dude, is this some kind of pity play for my girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yo, Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Craig SLAMS down the phone, crushing his finger in the process. He grimaces in pain, as Solomon approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I know, keep it down, I’m sorry. His point made, Solomon retreats back down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stumbles in, falls into bed. Muqtada stirs.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t have any friends. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MUQTADA
dialogues.text: This is very tough thing to learn. Craig looks to Muqtada, surprised to hear him respond. Af a beat, Muqtada rolls over in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly TRACK IN on a TEACHER at her desk, as students in their FRANKLIN GATES SUMMER SCHOOL applications. The teacher thumbs through them all, then addresses the class

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Huh... seems here someone neglected to turn in their Gates Summer application. Who is it that doesn’t want to study at Franklin Gates this Summer? Or eventually get into a good college? Get a good job? Have a good lifestyle? Get laid? I don’t understand why anyone would want to end up depressed, alone and homeless... in a psych ward... sleeping next to some asocial reject named Muqtada!? INT. CRAIG’S THREE NORTH BEDROOM Craig's eyes snap open in bed. TITLE OVER BLACK: “TUESDAY: DAY 3”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig lumbers slowly down the hall, when he hears a woman yelling with increasing volume. As he approaches the TV room, he peers inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN SCREAMS at Bobby. His daughter, VERONICA, who we recognize from the photo, watches in silence, while Roger observes nearby. Johnny lingers just outside the room.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Please lower your voice.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: How can you let your child see you like this? What kind of father are you? Bobby stares at his daughter across the table. She can’t look him in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear it’d be better for her if you were dead. But you can’t even get that right. Smitty hurries into the room with Solomon following after

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss, you’re going to have to leave now.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Waste of my time. The woman grabs the girl by the hand and leads her out.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: You okay, Bobby? Bobby nods, forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah... sorry about the noise, Sol. As Bobby exits the room, Craig tries to avoid eye contact but Bobby puts on another smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to Craig) My accountant... Check a wrong box and the bitch goes nuts. Craig chuckles, awkward. As Bobby continues down the hall Craig approaches Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: His ex. They make each other a little crazy. You know how it is with women.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Lynn visit with Craig. Jimmy stares out the window in the background.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I talked to the admissions guy at Gates and he agreed to give you an extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you should focus on getting well, honey. Try not to stress about it. Craig looks off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, that’s right. Don’t stress about it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: There’s a guy in here. Bobby. He's the one who borrowed your shirt. He has an interview today. For a place to live. He has a kid and if he doesn’t get in, they could be homeless. George and Lynn exchange uneasy looks.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Makes the Gates application seem pretty insignificant...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure you won’t be homeless if you don’t get in, but that doesn’t mean it’s not important.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Don’t you have a client in crisis somewhere? Beat. George stares at Craig.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It’1l come to ya!

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Yes, it will. Thank you. They all sit in tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a piece of paper labelled “FRANKLIN GATES PERSON ESSAY.” It is blank, except for a series of impressive doodles in the margins. Craig scribbles on the sheet as he sits alone in the rec room. His attention drifts to the door when Bobby enters, wear the borrowed shirt on his head like a turban. He looks totally dejected. Craig watches as Bobby tumbles onto the couch and SCREAMS into a pillow at full volume. He thrashes around on the couch like a child having a temper tantrum. After a few beats of this, Bobby rolls over onto his back makes eye contact with Craig. Hold, as Bobby’s breathing steadies. Nobody moves.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I blew it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What happened? Once again, Bobby screams at full volume, but this time h isn’t muffled by the pillow. Craig looks on, perplexed. Smitty and two MALE ATTENDANTS rush in, struggle to restr Bobby and usher him out of the room. INT. DR. MINERVA’S OFFICE - DAY Craig sits across from Dr. Minerva.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: How did it make you feel? Seeing Bobby like that.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I was scared... Not that he was going to hurt me or anything. Just seeing someone lose it like that. It reminded me of how I feel sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Like I’m on the verge of just blowing up. All the stress, pressure, anxiety bubbling up inside of me. But I’ve never been able to, you know, let it out like that. I just keep it inside.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Have you always felt that way?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, not when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Tell me about being a kid-- about a time you remember just being happy... Carefree. Craig thinks back...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: There was one day back in eighth grade...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Aaron, both a couple years younger, ride their bikes along the deserted boardwalk, laughing, having a ba

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that long ago, but time felt different back then, like there was more of it. We spent the morning at Coney Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Aaron run through a gaggle of seagulls, causing them to take flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race each other down the empty alleyways.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Afterwards, we rode our bikes through Bay Ridge.... FLASH ON Craig and Aaron cruising by a Pizza joint A76 in Bay Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...-Sunset Park... FLASH ON the duo eating tamales from a TAMALE VENDOR. B76

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ..-Park Slope...

dialogues.speaker: F76
dialogues.text: FLASH ON them flying by a gang of YUPPY MOTHERS, c7v6 pushing strollers. One of the moms yells at them to slow down.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...Downtown Brooklyn... FLASH ON Craig and Aaron buying a bootleg Lil Wayne CD D7 off a local STREET VENDOR.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .--Brooklyn Heights... FLASH ON them rolling along the Brooklyn Heights E76 Promenade.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .--all the way to the Brooklyn Bridge. FLASH ON the two of them rolling over the Brooklyn F76 Bridge. They pull over to the edge, lean over, and simultaneously spit on the taxis below. They crack up like two kids with a care in the world, until Aaron gets distracted by somet over Craig's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then everything changed. Following Aaron's gaze, Craig turns around, sees... ...a teenage girl eyeing Aaron from a few feet away. Aaro smiles at her. BACK TO DR. MINERVA’S OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Girls, grades, parents, two wars, impending environmental catastrophe, a fucked up economy... all these things seemed to come out of nowhere, like on the same day. Dr. Minerva smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Craig, there’s a saying that goes something like, “Lord, grant me the strength to change the things I can, the courage to accept the things I can’t, and the wisdom to know the difference.”

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: So, let’s talk about your parents.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You think I can change my parents?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: No, but I’m a psychiatrist. I have to ask you about them at some point. Craig smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: They’re good people. They do their best, but... Okay, take my dad. I just saw him today. And, like, he knows I’m in here cause I’m stressed out, but he still brings up the Gates application. It’s, like, get a clue, Dad. There’s something bigger going on here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: And what's that? Craig thinks for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m not sure yet. But it feels big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig listens to his voice messages. First up, A78& SPLIT-SCREEN of Nia, again in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: NIA
dialogues.text: Hey, Craig, I’m sorry Aaron was being such a dick. He’s so arrogant and insensitive. We might totally break up over this. Call me. Bye. Craig hits a button, and his goggled science teacher, B78 Mr. Reynolds, replaces Nia. He’s dissecting a cow heart.

dialogues.speaker: MR. REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Hey there, Mr. Gilner. Look, buddy, I heard about what’s going on, you know, where you are... and I want you to know we can postpone the labs until whenever you feel ready. Just hang in there.

dialogues.speaker: D78
dialogues.text: 78 Craig hits a button, and Aaron replaces Mr. Reynolds. C78 He talks on the phone as a harem of HOT GIRLS look throug his massive record collection in the background.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Hey Craig... Hope you’re not still mad about yesterday. It’s been a rough day for me. Nia and I broke up. Anyway, hope you're feeling better. I’m out. Craig hits a button, and this girl, JENNA, takes over D78 the split screen. She’s in the tub with Nia.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Hey, Craig, I’m Jenna, one of Nia’s friends, and like... okay, this is really embarrassing, but I heard about all this stuff you went through, and I kind of go through that stuff too. We met each other a couple times, but I always thought you were just weird. I didn’t realize you were, like, depressed. Anyway, I just think we should hang out, or whatever. Craig hangs up, shakes his head in disbelief, as Bobby 78 approaches. He drapes the borrowed shirt over Craig’s hea

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Craig removes the shirt, but Bobby continues down the hal He’s licking an ice cream cone. Craig rushes up to his si As they walk, other patients trickle out of their rooms a migrate with them towards the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sorry you didn’t get into the home.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No sweat, babe. I actually don’t find out for a few days... But I think I screwed the pooch.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m over it...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, but I’m zonked on Atavan SO...

dialogues.text: Where’d you get the ice cream?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mr. Softee truck across the street. They pass by Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Bobby-- Other migrating patients chime in.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I want ice cream.

dialogues.text: Can I have a lick, Bob?

dialogues.text: Two points off, Bobby.

dialogues.text: What’s with these points, anyway?

dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, what’s with these points?

dialogues.text: Nobody could possibly be keeping track of them...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Know why she’s here? Craig shakes his head. Bobby leans in, conspiratorial.

dialogues.text: Used to be a radical academic up at Columbia, but after they passed the Patriot Act, she got crazy paranoid. INT. A CUSTODIAN peeks in as he passes by the office. He stops his tracks, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Craig stares at Bobby in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Pretty loco, no? And Solomon? That guy’s nuts too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and a gang of other Hasids glide through the stre on roller-blades.

dialogues.text: Solomon was part of this cult of Hasidic acid-heads in Williamsburg. As he blades, Solomon sees buildings and cars melting everywhere. He lies down on his back, stares up at the stars. His BUDDIES approach on their blades, hover over h

dialogues.speaker: ACIDHEAD
dialogues.text: (in Yiddish with subtitles) I think Solomon did too much.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby finishes the story.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Did 100 tabs of acid in one night. Hasn't been the same since.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Crazy, right?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah... What about you? Bobby turns back to his food, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What about me? Craig backs off, shifts direction.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um... Your daughter. Veronica. When do you see her again? Bobby takes a bite. Chews and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think maybe she’s better off without me.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: C'mon, man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For real. I mean, I’m not exactly a role model in here. She's better off. Bobby nods, trying hard to convince himself.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Okay, so I know it’s none of my business and you can tell me to get lost if you want, but--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Get lost. Craig stares at Bobby for a tense beat, then looks down a his plate. Bobby shakes his head, frustrated with himself then...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Guess the Atavan wore off. Bobby gets up with his tray, pats Craig on the shoulder a passes.

Becca grabs the maracas with Noelle on tambouri Everybody has something, except Craig.

dialogues.text: Welcome back to musical exploration. Who doesn’t have an instrument? Noelle points to Craig.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: No worries, bro. Let’s get you up here on vocals.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I can’t sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like he can’t draw.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: C'mon... what’re you afraid of? Bobby nudges Craig, and he reluctantly heads up to the microphone, where Neil hands him a lyric sheet.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You know this one?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (looking it over) Um... I’ve heard it.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Good enough. Bobby and the ladies will help you out.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ladies? Neil SNAPS his fingers and right on cue, Nurse Monica lea other cute WEST INDIAN NURSES “on stage” to join Neil and Craig.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Okay, people, just like we practiced last week, here we go... Neil launches into the wicked bass-line from the classic David Bowie & Freddy Mercury rock anthem “Under Pressure” Craig stares at the lyric sheet, not sure when to jump in

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: C’mon, cool Craig. Let’s rock, babe. A84 Craig lowers his head, and at this moment the scene A shifts to PURE FANTASY, as the lights fade low and everyb appears in outrageous glam-rock costumes. The spotlight finds Craig. He’s a total rock star, dresse in a sparkling, skin-tight nylon jumpsuit with flaming be bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (as Freddy Mercury) Mm ba ba de... Um bum ba de... The fabulous nurses sway in unison behind him. A smoky mi fills the air.

dialogues.text: Pressure pushing down on me... Pressing down on you no man ask for... Under Pressure - that burns a building down, Splits a family in two, Puts people on streets... Um ba ba be... dialogues.text: It’s the terror of knowing what this world is about... Watching some good friends scream...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Let me out! Pray tomorrow - gets me higher...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Pressure on people, People on the streets... Jimmy chimes in from out of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Day day de... Da da da ba ba... Noelle steps up, shares the mic with Craig.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Chippin’ around - kick my brains around the floor... These are the days it never rains, but it pours...

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE/BOBBY
dialogues.text: People on the streets...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ee da de da de...

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE/BOBBY
dialogues.text: People on the streets...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It’s the terror of knowing what this world is about... Watching some good friends scream...

dialogues.text: Let me out!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray tomorrow - gets me higher high!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY /NOELLE
dialogues.text: Pressure on people - People on the streets. The song quiets down, and the Nurses snap their fingers i unison, as...

dialogues.text: Turned away from it all like a blind man... Sat on a fence but it don’t work...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Keep coming up with love, but it’s so slashed and torn...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Why? Whyyyy? Whyyyyyyy? Humble pounds on the drums, and music builds to a towerin crescendo, climaxing, as...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG/NOELLE
dialogues.text: Can't we give ourselves one more chance? Why can’t we give love that one more chance? Why can’t we give love give love give love give love... Johnny wails on the guitar like he’s been touring for yea as sparks shoot out of a pyrotechnic device behind him.

dialogues.text: This is our last dance! This is our last dance! This is ourselves...

dialogues.text: Under pressure... And the music fades, leaving only the sound of the nurses snapping their fingers, until...

dialogues.text: Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and about a billion other people. It’s alright, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Bob Dylan. It’s the song you just quoted.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh. Noelle laughs. Craig smiles too.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Anyway, my point is... I wanta play doctor with you. She cocks her head, intrigued. Craig SNAPS his fingers, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? He SNAPS again, looks down the hall.

dialogues.text: Where is he? After a beat, a commotion erupts from the opposite end of hall, as Bobby streaks naked through the corridor, howlin like a mad man. The nurses leave their station to help contain him. Noelle cracks up, as Craig ducks into the utility closet, snatches a pair of scrubs. They run off, sneaking through the emergency exit. Bobby notices Craig and Noelle escape, then stops running He smiles, as the nurses lead him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Noelle (disguised as doctors) emerge from the stairwell, blending into the crowd of doctors and patient

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Noelle stroll past EMERGENCY PATIENTS. When the see a SECURITY GUARD approaching from the opposite direct they quickly attend to the nearest patient, an old CHINES MAN. Craig rubs his head.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Does this hurt? Noelle massages his feet.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How about this? The guard passes without suspicion, so Craig and Noelle t off, leaving the Chinese man very confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Noelle jog down the hall, turn a corner to find ...-Dr. Minerva and her posse of interns coming towards t Craig and Noelle put on the brakes and scramble in the ot direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race up the stairs, find an exit door, and emerge ou onto...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-where the setting sun casts a fiery red glow on the Brooklyn rooftops. They take a beat to admire the Manhatt skyline and Brooklyn Bridge below.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: This is amazing. Craig looks at Noelle, reaches out, and touches her face. She doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You're not a cut fetishist, are you? Craig removes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Good. Those guys are so creepy. Craig smiles and they look out in silence.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How come you never asked me why?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Why what?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Why I did it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I guess I figured you’d tell me when you wanted me to know. Noelle smiles, nods.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Thanks. After a beat, Craig summons his courage.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Um... do you like music?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Um, yeah. Do you like breathing?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Dumb question.  Sensing his discomfort, Noelle lightens up.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I like Radiohead, Pixies, T Rex... What else... Craig nods. They sit in awkward silence, until...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Have you seen them live?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen Radiohead and the Pixies.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Cool... So... Um...

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Vampire Weekend's playing a show at the end of the month. Noelle pauses, giving him another chance. Craig just nods

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You wanta go? Craig smiles, an enormous weight has been lifted.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yes! I would. With you?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: No, with Smitty. Yes with me. They both continue to smile and look out over the sunset, until Noelle leans over, kisses Craig on the cheek, and w FREEZE mid-kiss--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sorry guys... This is about to get pretty sappy, so I’m just gonna give you the highlights. As Craig speaks in VO, we see various postcard-like still presented as a slide-show presentation.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is me sharing the realization that I don’t actually want to be a CEO, lawyer, or President. CLICK to the next slide of Noelle, mid-cackle.  CLICK to CLICK to CLICK to CLICK to CLICK to CLICK to out over

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is Noelle, laughing at the idea that I once wanted to be President. Noelle giving the world the finger.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here, Noelle suggests I “screw” the Gates Summer application if it makes me so unhappy. next slide of Craig, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is me liking that idea. Craig, no longer smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is me thinking about how to tell my dad. Noelle, blushing.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is after I tell Noelle how wonderful and beautiful she is. Craig and Noelle kissing.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oops. How'd that get in there? Noelle’s head on Craig’s shoulder, as they both look the sunset. Postcard text appears on screen: GREETINGS FROM ARGENON HOSPITAL. INT. DR. MINERVA’S OFFICE Back in normal attire, Craig sits across from Dr. Minerva

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I was having kind of a bad day. I missed dinner and breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I think I was probably just feeling scared about leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scares you about leaving?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: There are a lot more things to stress about on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Are you still having suicidal thoughts? Craig shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s like... there are so many people, not just in this hospital, but in the whole world, ya know, who are struggling so hard to live. And it seems like, self-indulgent, for me not to appreciate what I have.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, there’s my family, my home... and my friends... This girl. You know Noelle? Dr. Minerva raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Noelle? She’s the spunky one. Craig blushes slightly. Did she just call his girlfriend “spunky”?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Oh, and this... Craig reaches into his pocket, unfolds one of his brain m

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I always thought art was just bourgeois decadence, but... He hands the drawing to Dr. Minerva who looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: It’s really wonderful, Craig.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks. I did about twenty of them. It’s something I really enjoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you enjoy about it?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s fun. And it takes my mind off the stuff that stresses me out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Is this something you plan to continue when you leave?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe, but my Dad might freak.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: Have you told him how you feel?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: But you will. Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t know. As soon as I see him, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: And if he freaks? Craig thinks it over, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Better him than me. Dr. Minerva laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: That’s going to be the challenge... You ready? Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I think so. How am I doing? With the evaluation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, Craig... We've only just begun. The evaluation consists of three parts. There’s still the multiple choice section and a personal essay explaining why we should let you go... Craig stares at Dr. Minerva in shock.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: What? Doctors can’t make jokes too? Craig exhales in relief.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: You can leave first thing in the morning...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MINERVA
dialogues.text: You should stop by and say hi sometime. You know, we have a volunteer program with the local high schools. You could help others who are going through the same thing. Craig thinks it over, smiles and nods. INT. NURSES’ STATION - NIGHT Craig approaches Smitty, carrying the doctors’ scrubs.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Tonight’s my last night, Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Congratulations. We’1ll miss you, Craig.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: And Bobby’s too. You think we can have a pizza party?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Sure, if you can get the money.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How many pizzas do you think we need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we've got thirty patients and five staff, but that’s including Muqtada and the anorexics, so... seven pies should do.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (handing over the scrubs) Cool. Oh, I found these down over there somewhere. Smitty examines the scrubs, watches Craig go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig speaks into it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, seven large pies. All kinds... Just tell them to send the delivery guy to the third floor, Three North. Thanks, Dad. I’‘11 see you and mom tomorrow. Craig hangs up, looks down the hall, where... ..-Mugtada is peeking out their bedroom door. Craig waves but Muqtada just disappears back inside. Craig thinks for a beat, then picks up the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey, man... I could really use a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a completed stack of art beside him, Craig puts the finishing touches on a new brain map. Craig looks up as the security guard buzzes open the Thre North entrance doors, and George enters with six large pizzas.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey dad, I wasn’t expecting you in person.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I left work early. Thought it was more important to be here. Craig nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching) Mr. Gilner, thank you so much! Three North loves you tonight... (to Craig) See ya back there in a jiff? Smitty takes the pizzas from George, heads toward the din hall.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (ve: brain maps) Whatcha got there? Craig hands George the stack of brain maps. George looks through them. After a beat, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You did these? Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’ve been doing a lot of art in here, and it’s, um, actually... it’s something I’d like to continue.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Like, maybe, take a class this summer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What about the Gates program?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s not for me. Solomon runs by them, holding up his pants.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Craig! Have you heard about the pizza tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l be there in a minute, Sol. George takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Art's a wonderful hobby, but why don’t you hold off on any big decisions until you’ve gotten home, had some time to clear your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I’ve been doing here all week? I’ve thought a lot about it--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, let’s not close off your options. This could be very important for your future. Craig looks at George for a beat, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: What about now? I’m sixteen years old. Can’t I start worrying like an adult when I become one?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When I was your age--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Dad! I know you’re just trying to help, but you really stress me out sometimes. And that’s part of the reason I’m here. George takes this in. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: But after I leave tomorrow, I don’t ever want to have to come back. George nods, understanding the weight of this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Thanks for getting here and getting help.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Do you wanna come grab a slice with me? Meet some people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and George step into the room, where the patients c down on pizza. Craig spots Noelle, leads George to her.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Noelle, this is my dad. George.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Hi George. So what are you in for?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: She’s kidding, dad. George smiles and they shake hands, as Johnny steps by.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey, Johnny, meet my Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yo, thanks for the pies, Mr. G.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No problem... Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) Hey, have you seen Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Not since lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (looking off-screen) Oh, is that... Johnny and Craig follow George’s eyeline to the ping-pong table across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Johnny play doubles ping-pong vs. George and Noelle. His sleeves rolled, George plays like he’s known everybody for years.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Hey Craig, you have another visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig comes out to find Aaron texting on his phone. When sees Craig, he hands him a flat brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: I found it. I must have lent out the first two volumes. But here's the third.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I so appreciate this.  No problem..

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: - Look, man, I’m sorry I was a bitch to you.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I tried to make out with your girlfriend. Aaron and Craig nod at each other for an awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How are things with Nia?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: We're gonna try to work through it. Good.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: You know, I might hide it pretty well, but I get that depression stuff too, sometimes. Yeah? Aaron nods. Don’t kill I won't. Seriously. Thanks. Craig holds out his it into a hug. Aaron heads for the

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: yourself, okay?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: hand for Aaron to slap, but Aaron turns exit, but pauses one last time.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Did you really try to make out with Nia? Craig smiles and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Dick. Aaron exits and Craig heads back toward the party, but st when--

dialogues.speaker: NURES MONICA
dialogues.text: Craig... You left your drawings here earlier. Monica hands the stack to Craig, who looks closely at the on top: a custom drawn brain map that says “Bobby” at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks Monica. INT. BOBBY’S ROOM Craig peeks inside the room to find Bobby staring at the floor in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Pizza's getting cold. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Feeling pretty tired, think I’m gonna skip the pizza tonight. Just packing up.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So, vacation’s over...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yup. Back to work.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You got a job?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Nope. Beat. Craig shifts.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You know, I used your Dylan line on Noelle.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. We’re gonna hang out soon. See some music. Bobby smiles. Craig steps in, hands him a brain map.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Here. It’s you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yikes. It’s a mess in there.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It’s not such a mess. It’s just undergoing renovations. Bobby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I wrote my number on the back... let’s get together sometime... play some table tennis. Bobby thinks for a long beat, knowing this won’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Cool... So I’1l see you at breakfast tomorrow. Bobby nods. Craig starts to leave when...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Good luck, Craig.Not that you’1l need it.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks. You too, babe. They both smile and Craig exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig enters to find everyone chowing down on pizzas and rocking out to Smitty’s funk records. He smiles to himself, noticing George, now teamed-up with Professor, continuing to dominate other patients at the p pong table. Craig approaches Smitty and hands him the paper bag that Aaron brought.  Smitty removes an album from the bag: EGYPTIAN MASTERS: VOLUME 3. Smitty glances to Craig, and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Trust me. Smitty makes a face, but goes to the record player anyway The music cuts out mid-song, and some of the patients beg to grumble.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Just wait... The Egyptian Masters album soars into play.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: Hey, I like this. Yeah! Humble moves to the music.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Look! Becca points to the rec room entrance, where... ..-Mugtada is swaying to the rhythm, and tapping his feet

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey, Muqtada, join the party! Everyone gets down, and dances to the Egyptian Masters wi Muqtada at the helm. Near the rec room entrance, Bobby emerges in the doorway, observes for a quiet beat. He watches as... ...Craig heads over to Noelle in the corner. She smiles t Craig, wiggles her hips to the unusual music. They laugh, and Craig joins her in a little dance. Bobby smiles to himself and slowly backs out of the room. TITLE OVER BLACK: “FRIDAY”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the opposite end, Craig advances through the corrido with his duffel bag and a stack of brain maps. He passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: HUMBLE
dialogues.text: You should really stay longer; you might lose it on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I‘1l take my chances. Jimmy strolls by in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It’1l come to ya! Craig continues, passing patients and staff, saying his goodbyes.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I know you’re thinking, “What is this? Kid spends a few days in the hospital and all his problems are cured?” But I’m not. I know I’m not. I feel how easily I could fall back into it, lie down and not eat, look at my homework and freak out, look at Nia and be jealous... Smitty approaches, gives Craig his cell phone, keys, and shoelaces.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Thanks, Smitty. Have you seen Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: He already left. Early this morning. At first disappointed, Craig forms a slight smile.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But the difference between today and last Saturday is that giving up just isn’t an option anymore. Craig sees Noelle, his face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I feel like I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Craig?  They turn toward Lynn and George in the waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Wanta meet my mom?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You really move fast, don’t you? Craig’s parents approach.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Hey mom, this is Noelle.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey Noelle.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Hey George. Did you have fun last night?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I haven't partied like that since 1999. Craig rolls his eyes. Noelle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l let you go. Nice to meet you all.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: See you next week. Noelle smiles and struts off.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: (to George) What exactly went on here last night?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry, honey, what happens in Three North stays in Three North. Lynn elbows George.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Guys, can you go home without me and I’‘1l meet you back there in a few minutes?  Alaa

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Why? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I just want to ride my bike home.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure. We'll take your stuff. But hurry up; Alyssa baked you cookies. Lynn kisses Craig on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: See you in a few minutes. Lynn and George walk towards the elevator. Craig watches them for a beat, then glances back for one last look at T North, sees... ..-Mugtada, out of his room again, chatting with Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig steps out into the brisk spring air with the other PEDESTRIANS, COMMUTERS, and HOSPITAL LOITERERS. He goes t the bike rack, bends down and swirls the number rings to combination.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I know something’s changing in me. It might not be dramatic, but it’s real. And for the first time in a while, I can look forward to things I want to do in my life... Craig smiles into the camera. The following rapid-fire sequence takes us through Alaa wildly stylized images that correspond with Craig’s strea consciousness voice over...

dialogues.text: Bike. Eat. Drink. Talk. Ride the subway. Read. Read maps. Make maps. Make art. Have a party. Hug my mom. Kiss my dad. Kiss my little sister. Make out with Noelle. dialogues.text: CRAIG (V.O.) (cont'd) Draw a naked person. Draw Noelle naked. Run. Travel. Swim. Skip. I know it’s lame, but, whatever, skip anyway... Breathe. Breathe. Breathe. Live.

dialogues.text: He’s biking full speed. We TRACK with him for several bea but he’s just too fast. He flies out of frame, and we... CUT TO BLACK.
